awd_titl_txt: Single nanowire spin-valve based infrared photodetctors and equality bit comparators
awd_abstract_narration:
Infrared light is not visible to the human eye. It is usually detected with semiconductor detectors which exhibit a change in their electrical resistance under infrared illumination. The relative change in resistance at room temperature is, however, quite small, which necessitates cooling the detector with liquid nitrogen. In this research, a novel detector will be demonstrated, which relies on light changing the detector's resistance by affecting the quantum mechanical spin properties of the electrons that carry current. With this principle of detection, it is possible to make the resistance change in the detector much larger at room temperature. Room temperature infrared detectors are used in night vision, forensic science, astronomy, missile defense, car-collision avoidance systems and monitoring of global warming, to name a few.  Bit comparators are electronic devices that compare two digital (binary) bits of information and render a yes/no decision based on whether the two bits are the same or different. They are important ingredients of electronic circuits and are typically implemented with transistors which cannot remember the decision once the decision has been rendered. A comparator that exploits spin dependent properties and uses magnetic devices instead of transistors can remember the decision and also use less energy. The ability to remember makes it possible to build superior digital electronic circuits that are faster and more error-resilient. In this research, such a comparator will be demonstrated.  This project will also integrate research with graduate and undergraduate education, K-12 outreach through the Dean's Early Research Initiative program, and minority enrichment through the Richmond Minorities in Engineering Partnership.

This is a proposal to fabricate and demonstrate two novel spintronic devices - an infrared photodetector and a reconfigurable bit comparator - working at room temperature. They will be fabricated with 10- and 50-nm diameter nanowire spin valves with InSb spacer and cobalt contacts. In the InSb spacer, only a single electronic subband is occupied at room temperature. Preliminary experiments in the lab have shown that in these nanowires, the major spin relaxation mechanism of electrons - namely the D'yakonov-Perel' mechanism - is eliminated owing to single subband occupancy, resulting in several-fold increase in the spin relaxation time. It has also been shown that the spin relaxation time can be modulated with infrared light, which will be exploited to build the photodetector.  Such a photodetector can, in principle, exhibit near-zero dark current, giant light-to-dark contrast ratio and very high detectivity which always elude conventional photo-detectors because of phonon excitations. Controlling the magnetization state of a nanomagnet with electrically generated strain has been recently demonstrated in our lab. That property will be leveraged to build the reconfigurable bit comparator with unprecedented energy efficiency. These bit comparators are "non-volatile" since they incorporate magnetic elements and hence the result of the comparison can be stored indefinitely in the comparator. The devices will be fabricated with electrochemical self-assembly of nanowires, electron-beam lithography for patterning ferromagnetic contacts, and dielectrophoresis for capturing a single nanowire between a pair of contacts to implement the photodetector and bit comparator.

por.por_cntn:
Traditional electronics relies on the manipulation of electric charge within an electronic device to elicit the device?s functionality for computational or signal processing tasks. The drawback of this paradigm is that electric charges leak out of the device with time, thereby causing loss of stored information, which impedes efficient rendition of many electronic circuits. Additionally, manipulation of charge requires driving an electric current through the device and that can dissipate enormous amounts of energy. An alternate paradigm is to use tiny magnets in lieu of charge based devices as circuit elements. Information stored in the magnetic state of magnets is very long-lived and this attribute allows the design of more efficient circuits. Moreover, magnetic devices can be very frugal in their use of energy if the magnetic states are manipulated with mechanical strain that is generated with an electrical voltage. Thus, strain-switched nanoscale magnets offer an attractive alternative to charge based devices such as transistors. The field of controlling magnetic states in a nanomagnet with strain has been dubbed ?straintronics?. This NSF-funded project explored a variety of devices based on straintronics with an eye to establishing straintronics as a mainstream technology for computing and signal processing. 

Intellectual merit: During the tenure of this project, switching of the magnetization of a nanomagnet with strain, resulting in complete reversal of the magnetization was demonstrated. This established that strain-switched nanomagnets can act as the primitive digital switch in digital circuitry. Extensive material characterization of magnetostrictive materials, i.e. magnets which respond to strain, was carried out in order to understand and optimize straintronic devices. A large number of new devices and systems, such as miniaturized microwave generators, image processors, simulated annealers for non-Boolean computation based on strain mediated electric field control of magnetism were proposed and/or demonstrated. Additionally, antennas that radiate sound waves and memory devices based on entities called "magnetic skyrmions" that were controlled directly with an electric field without strain mediation, were experimentally demonstrated. In-depth theoretical simulations were carried out to understand how imperfections and defects in strain switched nanomagnets may impede their efficacy in computing, signal processing or signal generation. Considerable effort was also devoted to studying nanoscale self-assembly methods, based on a process known as ?dielectrophoresis? for fabricating nanostructures that could be leveraged for building state-of-the-art straintronic devices.

Broader Imapct: In the end, this project resulted in developing new technology, new understanding of physical phenomena and new simulation tools for design and analysis of straintronic devices. The project resulted in a few dozen journal publications, many invited or keynote talks in three continents, a few chapters in edited books, and one patent application. Additionally, three Ph.D. students and one M. S. student graduated and accepted employment at various industries. Two high school students were mentored and published journal papers based on their work related to this project. High school students from under-represented groups were hosted in the laboratories during summer and were trained in nanofabrication and nanocharacterization.
